title: 114_hr1640
content: The Act is titled the "Department of Homeland Security Headquarters Consolidation Accountability Act of 2015." It requires a report on the Department of Homeland Security Headquarters Consolidation Project. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in coordination with the Administrator of General Services, must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The report will detail the proposed occupancy plan for the Department of Homeland Security headquarters consolidation project in the National Capital Region, including information on operations, employees, and migration schedules. Additionally, it will include an assessment of the current and future real property needs of the Department in the National Capital Region. The Department of Homeland Security must provide a report to Congress detailing the current and needed capital assets and facilities in the National Capital Region to carry out its mission of securing the homeland and defending against terrorism. The report should also include plans for the construction of the headquarters consolidation at the St. Elizabeths campus, as well as a plan for the leased portfolio in the region. The Department of Homeland Security in the National Capital Region must provide details on rentable space, personnel, utilization rates, replacement and consolidation plans, including the number of employees expected to operate at each property, component, or office, and timing and leased terms for leased space. The Department of Homeland Security in the National Capital Region must provide details on rentable space, personnel, utilization rates, replacement and consolidation plans, including the number of employees expected to operate at each property, component, or office, and timing and leased terms for leased space. Additionally, a detailed list of alternatives considered during the development of the plan, along with an update of cost and schedule estimates for the consolidation project, must be completed within 180 days of the report submission. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the cost and schedule estimates for the National Capital Region to assess their quality and reliability. A report on the review results must be submitted to congressional committees within 60 days of the update completion. The term "National Capital Region" is defined in section 2674(f)(2) of title 10, United States Code. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The House of Representatives passed the document on June 23, 2015, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
